ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A strong understanding of how to perform a complex statistical project.
I learned to start a project of my own on something that I feel passionate about and look for data, clean it, and make a good exploratory analysis of the data.

This course provided me with a peek into the research world of statistics and applied statistics. I enjoyed meeting with my advisor each week to discuss my work, consider changes/improvements to my methods, and determine next steps. Also, the task of explaining my research to individuals who are not familiar with the field was more challenging than I expected.
I was able to apply everything Ive learned in the past four years to a project.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The open format was great and allowed for me to finish my project without stressing.

If you find a supportive advisor or have an idea you really wanna do on your own, this is a good option. There's not much support from the S&DS department, so don't expect to be guided through the project. Also, start early (perhaps even the semester before). Dealing with messy data, if that is relevant to your project, can really cut into time spent working on it. Could be improved with more detailed expectations from the S&DS department. If you don't have friends in the major, it would probably be very isolating to do this class.
Strengths: A lot of freedom on your project and a great mentor to guide you through the process.

I thoroughly enjoyed everything about this course. The research itself was very intellectually challenging yet rewarding, and the final poster presentation was a great way to see the interesting work that other students produced. That being said, there is almost no structure to the course, and so each student is responsible for their progress throughout the semester. I would not call this a weakness of the course but rather a reflection of the real world. If you take this course, be sure you dedicate the requisite time necessary to be successful.
It was a great opportunity for independent study.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I had a very helpful and responsive advisor, and I enjoyed doing a project (as opposed to a capstone course) because of the freedom and self-direction I was able to have. Would recommend if you can find a good advisor!
Yes if you find a good advisor early and have an idea you're interested in! No if you cannot time manage a large project by yourself
Yes, it is a great opportunity to do a project on something that interests you and that you feel passionate about.

If possible, complete a senior project! You have the opportunity to work one-on-one with a leading researcher in the field of statistics (when else in your life would you be able to do this) on a topic in which you are interested. You will get close to your advisor throughout the semester, so the course also serves as a great mentorship opportunity.

Yes, do a project instead of taking 425/625. It is good for you. I did both and I thought while 425/625 was super rewarding, 492 should definitely be hyped up more. It is so satisfying to work towards something big during the entire semester and be able to call it your own and submit it!
I think S&DS majors should consider taking this course as part of their major requirements. The freedom to choose topics and learn from experts in the area is great.
Yes! You have more autonomy over your project than the other course.
